data.title: Where to Go in Nicosia?
data.meta_description: Cyprus Nicosia is one of the most beautiful, striking, charming and unique corners of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.
data.text:
Where is Nicosia?

Where is Nicosia? Nicosia is the capital city of Cyprus. It is located in the central part of the island, near the center of Cyprus. Nicosia is the largest city in Cyprus and serves as the political, economic, and cultural center of the country.

The city is unique in that it is divided into two parts: the southern part, which is under the control of the Republic of Cyprus, and the northern part, which is controlled by the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC). The dividing line, known as the "Green Line," is a result of the ongoing division of the island, which has persisted since 1974.

Places to Visit in Nicosia

There are many places to visit in Nicosia, offering a mix of historical, cultural, and modern attractions. Here are some notable places to explore in the city.

Kyrenia Gate

Kyrenia Gate is one of the original gates of Nicosia's Venetian walls, built by the Venetians in the 16th century. It's a historic entrance to the old city.

Venetian Column

The Venetian Column is located at the heart of Nicosia, known as the "Lion's Square." It's a symbol of the city's Venetian past.

Selimiye Mosque

Formerly known as the St. Sophia Cathedral, this mosque is a significant historical and architectural landmark in Nicosia. It was built in the 13th century and converted into a mosque during the Ottoman era.

Museum of Barbarism

The Museum of Barbarism is located within Nicosia's walls and documents the history and events surrounding the Cyprus conflict and division.

Nicosia Walls

The Nicosia Walls are a series of defensive walls built around the old city of Nicosia. These walls were constructed by the Venetians in the 16th century to protect the city from invaders.

Bedesten St. Nicholas Church

The Bedesten, a historic market building, was originally built as a church dedicated to St. Nicholas. It has since been used for various purposes and is a notable architectural structure.

Derviş Pasha Mansion

Derviş Pasha Mansion is a well-preserved example of Ottoman architecture and serves as a museum today, offering insights into the history of Nicosia and Cyprus.

Great Khan

The Great Khan is an Ottoman-era caravanserai used as a marketplace and place of rest for travelers and merchants. It's a beautiful architectural structure in the city.

Long Road Street

Long Road Street, also known as Ledra Street or Lidras Street, is one of the most famous streets in Nicosia, the capital city of Cyprus. This pedestrianized street is located in the heart of the city and is a bustling center of commerce, culture, and history. Here are some key points about Long Long Road Street being a popular destination for both tourists and locals due to its numerous shops, boutiques, cafes, and restaurants. You can find a wide range of products, from clothing and jewelry to souvenirs and local crafts.

Long Road Street is lined with shops and boutiques offering a variety of products. It's a great place to shop for clothing, accessories, and traditional Cypriot goods.

The street is home to numerous cafes and restaurants where you can enjoy Cypriot and international cuisine. It's a great spot for leisurely meals or a coffee break.

The street occasionally hosts cultural events, live music, and outdoor performances, creating a vibrant atmosphere.

Located on Long Road Street, the Shacolas Tower offers an observation deck with panoramic views of Nicosia and is a popular attraction for visitors.

The British Colonial Courts

These courts, part of the British colonial legacy, played a significant role in Cyprus's legal system during British colonial rule.
